South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: DAILY WEATHER REPORT
div.p: OBSERVATIONS BY THE SURVEY DEPARTMENT.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: A break has taken place in the weather, and there is a return to normal conditions. Rain continued to fall till yesterday, the rainfall for the 48 hours amounting to 1 inch. The rainfall for the month of November was 4.25 inches. today is warmer, the sky is clear, and the barometer rising.

div.head: King's Royal Rifles.
div.p: The 3rd King's Royal Rifles are to send 135 men in February to their 1st Battalion in Egypt.

div.head: Cairo Police.
div.p: The Government has transformed the post of assistant commandant of police in Cairo into that of chief inspector.

div.head: Lots Turce.
div.p: The winner of the "gros lot" at Saturday's drawing of Ottoman Railway Lottery bonds was the holder of No. 726,302.

div.head: Ministry of Education.
div.p: The Government has decided to appoint a private secretary to the Minister of Public Instruction, in compliance with his request.

div.head: Zifta Irrigation Circle.
div.p: the post of director of Zifta Barrage has been abolished. The barrage works will in future be directed by the inspector of Zifta Circle.

div.head: Horrible Domestic Tragedy.
div.p: A native of Zagazig has been found dead with his arms cut off and his entrails extracted from his body. It is rumoured that the murders were hired by the man's son and wife, who were opposed to his marrying another woman.

div.head: Army Inspections.
div.p: Col. J. Magill. M.D., C.B., R.A.M.C., P.M.O in Egypt, accomplished by Major F.W. Hardy, M.B., R.A.M.C. Sanitary Officer, will make the annual inspection of barracks and hospitals and Det. R.A.M.C., at Alexandria on the 11th and 12th inst.

div.head: Death from Drink.
div.p: Yesteray evening, a Sudanese was found the police in an advanced state of intoxication in Sisters' street, and removed in a comatose state to the Government Hospital, where he expired shortly afterwards. The postmortem examination showed that death was due to the effects of intoxication.

div.head: Husband Kills Wife.
div.p: A quarrel between a native and his wife in the Lavbbane quarter yesterday had fatal results. The man, who is a sexuagenarian, was in a drunken state, and administered such a thrashing to his wife in the course of an altercation, that the poor woman succumbed to his blows shortly afterwards. The husband was arrested.

div.head: Mile Marthe Brandes.
div.p: This celebrated French comedienne, who has already adone at Vienna, Budapest, Bucharest, Constantinople, Smyrns, and Athens is coming here, and will appear at the Zizjnia on Saturday next to "Francillon." Her other performance billed are "Le Passe," "l'Espionne," "Amoureuse," "l'Adversaire," "Les Tenailles," "La Rafale."

div.head: Postal Notice.
div.p: The Post Office issue a notice to the effect that persons wishing to receive their correspondence at the distribution windows of post offices are earnestly requested to take the necessary steps to have such letters addressed "Poste Restante." Those who subscribe to special boxes will facilitate sorting by having the number of their box put on their address.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: On the 29th November, 9 vessels, 5 northward and 4 southward bound, transited the Canal, and paid transit and passenger toll Fr. 244,471.66 Of these vessels, 4 were British, 2 Japanese, 1 Dutch, 1 Norwegian, and 1 Ottoman. The total revenue since November 1 is Fr. 8,538,030.22. During this period, 305 vessels transited the Canal, 138 northward and 167 southward bound.

div.head: The Princess's Necklace.
div.p: We are glad to hear that the Governor General of the Suez Canal, Mohamed Moheb Bey, has interested himself in the case of the nephew of M. Vellardi, the hairdressor of Port Said, who had found and restored to the Princess of Coosh Behar a pear necklace that she had lost. The Governor congratulated him on his honesty and gave him a gratuity out of his own pocket, promising to intercede in his behalf with the Indian Princess.

div.head: New Banks.
div.p: A new bank is being erected at Tantfor the Anglo-Egyptian Bank from plans of Mr. Robert Williams, F.R.I.B.A. The walls are brick with Doulting stone dressings from the Chelynch Beds of the Ham Hill and Doulting Stone Company. The main entrance is of stone and forms the chief feature of the building, which stands in a commanding position. Mr. Williams has also prepared plans for a new bank at Port Said for the same banking company.

div.head: Wrestling at the Alnambra.
div.p: Angelo Bazzerini, Alexandria's champion, has had his offer to enter the lists refused by the committee, who desire the programme to run its course without change. On the other hand, the other champions have accepted his offer for a 50 frano prize. tonight the following bouts take place at 9 p.m. for the international championship of 5,000 francs Mohamed v. Salama Assine; Limousin v. Karl Cylis; Schackmann v. Milo; oattinger v. Ahmed Ay; Paul Pons v. Eigmann.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways.
div.p: From 1st December the following will be the fares for births in the train de luxe running between Cairo and Luxor and vice versa. Between Cairo and Beni Sonef P.T. 35; Miuia P.T. 50; Assiont, P.T. 70; Sohag, P.T. 90; Nag Hamadi, P.T. 90; Keneh, P.T. 100; Luxor, P.T. 100.

div.head:
SIRDAR AT-EL OBEID.
PRESENTS FROM ALI DINAR
div.p: Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, Governor General of the Sudan, arrived at El Obeid, on his tour of inspection in Kordofan, on the 28th ulto. On entering the town the Sirdar was met by 1,500 horsemen belonging to different tribes. A review of the troops was afterwards held by his Excellency. Messengers from Ali Dinar, Sultan of Darfour, were present, and brought three magnificent stallions as presents for the Governor General.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL STEAMER AGROUND.
div.p: Suez, Sunday.

The Khedivial Mail liner Neghilleh, which had been chartered for 14 days by a petroleum exploration company, was reported today by the coast guard cruiser Nour el Bahr to be aground at Gemsab, near Gebel Zeit, in the Gulf of Suez. At the time of grounding she apparently was in charge of a Red Sea Pilot. The company's steamer Callioubieh was despatched this day at noon to her assistance.

div.head: SUEZ FULL OF PILGRIMS.
div.p: Suez, Sunday

Suez at the present moment is quite full of Egyptian and foreign pilgrims en route to (almost every day special pilgrim trains arrive with hundreds of pilgrims. in all parts of the town these people are being lodged, and the train is consequently in a very dirty condition. Thanks, however, to the frequent sailings of the Khedivial steamers for Jeddah we are gradually getting rid of our visitors.

div.head: DEPARTURE OF ROYAL BERKS.
div.p: The 1st Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment left Cairo last night by special train for Suez, where it embarked on the transport Dongola Today for Karachi, India

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Yesterday's bulletin recorded two cases (one fatal) and a death at Ghirgeh, and one recovery at Salalout. Today's bulletin records two fresh cases and two deaths at Ghirgeh, and four cases and two deaths at Nag Hamadi.

div.head: NEW MUNICIPALITIES.
div.p: It has been decided to create four new municipalities in the provinces, one at Akhmin, Ghirgheh province, the second at Simbellawein, Dakhalieh Province, the third at Sennoures, Fayoum province, the fourth at Eneh, Keneh Province. The Minsitry of Finance has allowed for the first a credit of L.E. 1,500, and L.E. 1,200 for each of the others. It has also been decided to increase the yearly grant for Tantah and Mansourah Municipalities by L.E. 1,000 so that the credit allowed for each will now amount to L.E. 5,000. The credit for Damanhour Municipality has been increased by L.E. 1,000, bringing it up to L.E. 3,000. Other municipalities whose credits have been increased are the following: Suez, from L.E. 3,000 to L.E. 3,500; Damietta and Minieh, from L.E. 1,000 to L.E. 2,400; Assouan, from L.E. 2,000 to L.E. 2,500; Beni Souef, from L.E. 1,800 to L.E. 2,500; Benha from L.E. 1,350 to L.E. 1,800; Ghirgheh, from L.E. 1,300 to L.e. 1,750.

div.head: GORDON MEMORIAL COLLEGE.
div.p: In a prefatory note to the annual report of the Gordon Memorial College of Khartoum, Sir Reginald Wingate, Governor General of the Sudan, observes: 'I entirely agree with Mr. Currie (the principal) that there need to be no mi givings that the Gordon College is developing into an instituion for turning out supe flaous clerks. On the contrary, the Government are in a position to take a very much larger number of boys to fill the minor apartmeents in the various departments than the college can possibly furnish, and a long timnet elapse before the supply can in any ae meet the demand. It will be interesting to observe how the young sheikhs, who have just completed their five years course, and are about to take up work in the Mohamedan to the training and education they have acquiredin the college. There is every reason to hope that their entry into the "Government service will mark an important epoch in the country's development and progress."

div.p: MOERIS HOTEL (on the Lake.) AND GRAND HOTEL KAROUN Fayoun
Comfortable Hotels Patronised by Princess of Battenberg, Prince of Sweden, etc.

div.head:
DEPARTING FRENCH MINISTER.
BANQUET IN CAIRO
div.p: A farewell was given yesterday evening to M. de la Bouliniere, French Diplomatic Agent (who is leaving Cairo for Athens) by the French colony of Cairo, at the Continental Hotel. The spacious drawing room of the hotel was converted for the occasion into a banqueting all and the tables, which were arranged in horse shoe fashion, were most artistically decorated with red and white roses relieved by maidenhair ferns. On the right of M. de la Bouliniere was M. de Reffye, who succeeds him as Diplomatic Agent in Cairo, and on his left was M. de Valdrome. Among the other 150 guests were M. Vanei, M. Maspero, M. de Kramer, M. Barois, President Prunieres, Dr. Brossard, M. Picelli, and Chelu Bey.

At the conclusion of dessert M. Vaneri, depute de la nation, in an eloquent speech expressed the great regret of the whole French colony at the severance of heir connection with M. de la bouliniere, whose services daring his four years stay in Cairo had been highly steemed. In wishing M. de la Bouliniere every success in his new appointment which he was about to assume, he expressed the sentiment of not only those who were present but of the united colony.

M. Maspero, in handing an illuminated address to M. de la Boulinere, which was signed by all attending the banquet, echoed the wishes of M. Vaneri, saying that this act of homage was but an evidence of the retiring Diplomatic Agent's immense popularity among those whom he represented in this country, and to a man who had faithfully fulfilled his allotted duty.

After M. de la Boulinere's reply, in which he expressed the great regret with which he left his many friends in Egypt, and his gratitude for the only too kind and flattering sentiments to which he had just listned, the band of the Inniskilling Dragoons, which supplied the music for the occasion, under the condactorship of Mr. Prosser, struck up the "marseillaise," at the conclusion of which the guest of honour made his departure, shaking hands with all present.
It only remains to say that the banquet was most sumptuous, and under the direct supervision of Mr. Braun, even excelled the previous menus of the Grand Continental Hotel on similar occasions.

div.head: ST. ANDREW'S DAY.
div.p: The St. Andrew's Dinner on Friday night was a great and notable sucess. Shepheard's Hotel excelled itself, and provided a flat-rate menu and first-rate wines. The Haggis was solemnly "played in" by the bagpipes, and a telegram sent to Mr. James Hewa at Alexandris, to whose patriotism and generosity the company owed the famous dish. The band of the Inniskilling Fusiliers played throughout the dinner and the haunting charm of the Northern melodies must have awakened many memories, pleasant and pathetic. All the usual toasts were proposed and drunk. Mr. Mitchel-Innes, the chairnman, made a really fine speech for the "Land o' Cakes." Mr. Monteith Smith, Mr. Dicey; C.B., Mr. D.E. Clark, Mr. Ross Taylor, and Mr. B. Thomson were all eloquent and amusing. There were 39 present in all, and among them Harvey Pasha, Messrs. McGillivray, Granville, Scott Monorieff, Hewitt; and we must not forget Mr. Murray, the piper, who came in "fall kit," kilt and all. In fact, it was a memorable and delightful function, and it is to be hoped that St. Andrew's Day will always be as genially and loyally celebrated in Egypt as it was last Friday.

div.head: ZIZINIA THEATRE.
div.p: One of the first needs of a critic is self-assurance, yet there was occasions on which those bolder than ourselves might reasonably quail; such as, for instance, the performance of "Bar Kohba," a melodrama acted in Yiddish and dealing with a half forgotten period of Jewish history. That such a play can find in Alexandria a large and appreciative audience is proof, if one were needed , not only of the size but also of the constancy and enthusiasm of the Jewish community. Their able support to Saturday's performance will be a welcome contribution to the funds of the "Gmilet Hered," in aid of which charity the entertaiment was given.
The acting as well as the incidental music, were apparently of no very high order, while the stage management was distinctly poor.

div.head:
KHEDIEVE AND THASSOS.
CLAIM SUPPORTED BY ENGLAND.
div.p: Our Constantinople Correspondent is informed that the question of Thassos has become international, and that the Khedive, supported by England, is making a claim to the port on the island and to the foreign mining concessions given by Turkey to a Geran company. The Khedive, who also opposes the concession for a cable between Thassos and Thendos, says the island belongs to him

The news that the Khedive is again actively pressing his claim to the little island of Thassos revives the memory of one of the curiosities of Oriental history. Thassos does unquestionably belong to the descendants of Mehemet Ali, despite the fact that it is geographically a mere detail of the Macedonian coast. That great soldier of fortune was a native of Kavalla, the port of the Macedonian tabacco trade, which faces Thassos across a narrow strip of sea. The Khedive Mehemet never forgot that he was an Albanian by original and a Macedoanian by birth, and to this day the theological students of Kavalla are fed by the bounty of his heirs. Thassos was given to him in 1841, after his great revolt, when his rights over Egypt were made hereditary. In those days the Sultans were very ready to oblige their great vessal, and to take advantage of the military strength of Egypt. It was an Egyptian army which overran and devastated Greece when the Turkish forces had failed to reduce it, during the war of independence, and later, it was an Egyptian army which reconquered insurgent Crete and occupied it till 1840. Economically and politically the island, poor enough today, despite its ancient gold mines, has possibilities. It lies on the sea road to Constantinople, and it also commands Kavalla, which might under certain conditions, rival Salonka as the great port of the Egean; it has, moreover, considerable mineral wealth, as the German syndicate which is now exploiting it has discovered. We have a double interest in assisting the Khedive to maintain his rights. For while we are his natural protectors in Egypt, it also happens that Kavalla falls within the section of Macedonia which our officers are helping to on Thassos, which is uncomfortably near the Straits, might have large consequences.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive is spending the day at Abdeen Palace. This morning his Highnesss granted audiences to the Ministers, the Portugese Diplomatic Agent (who presented the new Portugese judge for Mansourah Tribunal), and Sheikh Mohamed Chakir.

div.head:
MINISTRY OF EDUCATION.
EXAMINATINO IN ARABIC.
div.p: The following candidates passed the exam nation in arabic held last month.
ADVANCED EXAMINATION.
Stewart, Adam Bell; Mathematical and Science Master, School of Agriculture, Ghizeh.
ELEMENTARY EXAMINATION.

Baker, Arthur; Instructor, School of Engineering, Ghizeh. Daniell, Philip Foster; Mathematical and Science Master, Tewfikieh School, Cairo. Hardie, Patrick Sinclair; Mathematical and Science Master, Ras-el-Tin School, Alexandria. Sharples, James William; Mathematical Master, Khedivieh School, Cairo. Smith, Stanley Rivera; Mathematical Master, Saidieh School, Cairo.

div.head: AL AZHAR.
div.p: The recent squabble in Al Azhar seems to have been due to the opposition of the more conservative among the ulema to the action of Sheikh Mohamed Shakir, acting Chancellor of the University, in appointing three new commissions to undertake the examination of graduates. The matter was duly reported to the Khedive, who however, reserved his judgement until the 26th November, when, in recieving the ulema at Abdeen Palace, he expressed the desire that Sheikh Mohamed's measures should be carried out, as they were to the benefit of the studnts.
"Thousands of pounds," added his Highness, "are being yearly spent on AlAzhar, but if differences such as these continue we shall be obliged to dispose of the money in some other way."
This statement of the Khedive is held to be a warning to the ulema opposed to the Sheikh, who enjoys the Khedive's patronage.

The Islamic Press of Cairo is dissatisfied with the present condition of Al Azhar. "Al Moayad," in a series of articles from Moslem quills, calls for reform and State intervention in the affairs of this university.
To promote the study of mathematics, Sheikh Mohamed ordered the issue of special certificates for arithmatic and algebra, and at the last general examination thirty students crassed.

div.head: COOK'S NILE SERVICES.
div.p: The following is the list of passengers by the P.S. Hatason, which left Cairo on Friday

Mrs. M.G. Keel, Mr. H.S. Collins, Prof. H. Goudy, Mr. E. Baumaun, Miss C. M. Sullivan, Miss C. A. Olding, Miss Mannering, Misses A. and Miss D. Mannering, Miss Edith Latham, Miss Cora Steeds, Mr. Julius Reinhard, Dr. Westhaus, Mr. E.N. Dawson, Mr. and Mrs. A. E. Barco, Mr. and Mrs. W.H. Chapman.

div.head: THE NATIONAL UNIVERSITY.
div.p: THE COMMITTE'S HOPES.

The committee fo the proposed National University met on Friday evening at the residence of Hassan Bey Gamjoun at Cairo. It was announced that, Saad Pasha Zighloul, the new Minister of Education, who was vide president of the commmittee, had resigned owing to his new appointment; and Kassim Bey Amin, secretary to the committee, was appointed in his stead. The latter delivered a speech dealing with the committee's work, and said that H.H. the Khedive would be pleased to place the University under his patronage Albeit the Governnment appeared to consider the scheme premature, the authorities did not view it with disfavour. The Government feared that the committee's efforts would prove abortive, but "I think," said Amin Bey, "I am not wrong in saying that the Government will not refrain from helping us in the future when we have acted wisely and with energy."
The new vice-president suggested that the subscriptions should be taken in hand at one throughout the country.
The commmittee hope that one of the Princess of the Khedivial family will accept the post of president.
The subscriptions which have been collected in aid of the scheme up to date amount to L.E. 10.836.

div.head:
SLEEPING CAR CO. IN EGYPT.
NEW RESTAURANT OPENED.
div.p: The International Sleeping Car Company celebrated the opening of its new buffet restaurant and bar at the Bab-el-Ghedid terminus, Alexandria, by a barquet on Saturday evening. Among those who accepted the invitation of Mr. Tite, the popular representative of the company in Egypt, were Mr. Purser, the manager of teh Goods Department of the Egyptian State Railways, Mr. Grundy, general railway superintendent of Alexandria, Mr. Pearson, divisional railway superintendent of Lower Egypt, Mr. Hylands, divisional railway superintendent of Cairo, Mr. Toureille, director of the Domains Section of the Enginering Department, representatives of Messrs. Thos. Cook and Son (Egypt), Limited, and a number of representatives of the European and native Press. After the many and various items of an excellent menu had been gone through Mr. Grundy, as the Alexandrian representative of the Egyptian State Railways, rose and made an eloquent speech in honour of the occasion. He expressed a hope that the inauguration of the new restaurant in Alexandria would be the beginning of a new era in Egypt, and that many more of the larger stations throughout the length and breadth of Egypt would soon be endowed with similar gastronomic establishments. He stated that he had the pleasure of Mr. Tite's acquaintance for many years, an everything that the gentleman had done to advance the interests in Egypt of the great company, which so worthily represented, had met with complete access, and he consequently had no fears as to the future of the institution which they were inaugurating. Mr. Grundy concluded his discourse by caling on all present to join him in toasting Mr. Tite, an invitation which, it is needless to say, was most heartily responded to.

Mr. Tite, in reply, regretted his inability to rival the first speaker's eloquent oration, and thanked the company for the cordial manner in which they had expressed theigood wishes towards the company and himself. He regretted that many had been unable to attend the banquet from Cairo owing to the epidemic of dengue fever, and went on to state that this was the first of the first-class restaurants which teh International Sleeping Car Company intended introducing throughout the principal railway stations in Eypt. A restaurant had been already started in tantah and had met with great success and they had also met with great success and theyhad also restaurants at Port Said and Zagazig. Their aim was to provide the very best fod and drink for their clients the public, and he hoped that in time every one of the larger stations throughout the country would be furnished with a buffet by the company. He had every confidence that the new restaurant at Alenxandria would fil a long-felt want of the travelling public and of visitors arriving from Europe, and in addition to the restaurant and bar, a cloak room and other conveniences had been installed. A good lunch and a good dinner would be always available and there would also be an a la carte service. In conclusion he desired to think the representatives of the Press present for the support which the newspapers had always given to the company and also for thier attendance at the ceremony that evening.

The editor of "Al Minbar" replied with some wall-chosen remarks delivered in perfect English. Mr. Parser then rose and dwelt on the hamonious relations that had always existed between the Egytian State Railway Administration and the International Sleeping Car Company, whos receipts in Egypt were advancing rapidly. He remarked that the Administration could not entrust travellers to better hands than those of the company and he was most pleased to testify to the cordial manner which characterised the relations of the Government Railways and the company. After a speech in French by M. Toureille, the proceedings came to a close.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: We are sorry to learn that Mustapha Pashe Fehmy, the Prime Minister, has been confined to bed for the last three days owing to slight indisposition.

Among the passengers by the S.S. Hohenzollern, which arrived at Alexandria from Marsailles today, were the children of the late Prince Mohamed Ibrahim, who were in the charge of Mrs. Carton de Wiart; Prince de Chimay, the Duc di San Vito Carscciolo, Cherif Pasha, Baron Albuquerque, Mr. and Mrs. N. R. Nelson, the well-known American Society couple, Miss Nelson, Mr. Charles F. Cole, Miss D. Leveaux Mrs. Julia A. Graves, Mrs. A. N. Royce, Mr. G.F. Blackburne Daniel, Mr. H. Henman, Mrs. F. L. Stack, Mr. and Mrs. Alexandre de Zogheb, and Mr. and Mrs. G. W. Moore.

Among the passengers who arrived yesterday by the Italian S.S. tebe were Count Carlo Rasponi, Italian Deputy. Count Vittore Siciliani di Morreale, Italian Consol in Cairo, Marchese Guiseppe Fioravanti, Sig. Leoncavallo and family.
Lady Arnold is coming to Egypt by the P. and O. steamship India for a tour.

Rear Admiral C.J. Barlow, D.S.O., who becomes vice admiral by the retirement of Vice Admiral G.C. Langley, was born in 1848, and served with distinction in Egypt 1882, and in Burmah 1885-6, gaining the D.S.O. in the latter campaign. He has been Superintendent of Pembroke Dockyard, and was subsequently appointed second in command of the Home Fleet.

Baron Sir R. von Slatin Pasha, Inspector General of the Sudan, has been the recipient of many congratulatory messages upon the distinguished honour conferred upon him by His Majesty the Emperor of Austria.

While at polo at Suez last week, Moberlay Bey was thrown from his house and sustained serious injuries in the face. He has been granted sick leave, and another official appointed to replace him temporarily in the governorship of Tourah prison.
Captain S. J. Somerville, 2nd Royal inniskilling Fusiliers, has been granted a month's leave of absence.

Among the latest arrivals at the Savoy, Port Said, we notice: Messrs. Cattani, Miss Estridge, Miss Emerson, Mr. and Mrs. Hardman, General and Mrs. Miles, Mr. Whitworth Jones, Lieut. F. Clark, Capt. Sir Barthelot, Major Hoskins, Sir R. Oakes, Sir-- and Lady Cable, Capt. Dunbar, M. and Mme Holty, Lieut. Holland, Mr. S. Davidson, Sir John Rogers, Baron and Baronnne de Montesquieu, Mr. Pothecarry, Mr. F. boerger, Mr. W. M. Russel, Mr. Biddulph, Miss Rogers, M and Mme tobit, M. and Mme Lauzon, Mr. Mullinyhaus, Mr. e. Wellrook, M. and Mme Rutschi von Haller.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: A meeting of the Municipal Commmission will be held on Wednesday next, when the following business will be transacted:
1. Rapport du Comite special et avis de la Delegation sur:
a) la question des nouvelles resources.
b.)la location decertains terrains des quais
la concession a bail d'un terrain sur les quais pour la construction d'un Casino.
2. Lettre de M. Joseph au sujet de la jeteepromenade.
3. Interpellation de M. Kamel Bey Teymour sur la question de la route de la Corniche.
4. Interpellation et proposition de Mr. M. Salvago sur l'etat des rentes, leur entretien et l'encombrement des trottoirs.
5. Demande de credit de L.E. 45, a titre supplementaire pour le Service de la desinfection.
6. Excedents et emprises.
Vente des terrains.

div.head: SOCIETE KHEDIVIALE DE GEOGRAPHIE.
div.p: Pen de monde a l'iauguration de la nouvelle session. ou n'aime pas evidemment perre les vendredi et ses attraits et nons consellions a la Societe de Geographie de revenir a ses samedis.

Toutefois la quantite etait compensee par la qualite et mettons en e e le prince de geographes, le Dr. Schweinfarth; nous avons remarque aussi le voyageur Eram, S.E. Fakri Pacha, S.E. Artin Pacha, Boinet Bey, jages Prampolini et Azz, un bon nombre de dame, etc.

La seance a commence par la commemoration de feu le Comte Regnault de Bissy, Colonel du Genie francais et membre honoraire de la Societe. M. Bonola Bey a. detaille les services, eminents rendus a la geographio africaine par l'ancien directeur du Service des Cartes en France et specifie la valeur de sa Grande Carte d'Afrique au 2,000,000 en 72 feuilles, qui est un veritable monument scientifique. A la fin l'assemblee, su l'invitation du President, s'est levee une fois en l'honeur de la memoire du regrette savant.

S.E. Abbate Pacha a pris er suite la parole pour relater ses impressions, lors de sa visite au Vesuve, qulques semaines apres la terrible eruption de cette annee. Il a expose aussi une superbe collection de photographies et des echantillons de lave.
M. Bonola Bey a ensuite rendu compte de ce qu'il a trouve d'interessant au point de vue de la geographie a l'Exposition de Milan.
Les deux communications, qui ont occupe une heure, out ete suivies aveo attention par l'auditoire et vivement applandies.

div.head: BULLETIN DE L BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hus a midi demie.)

La plupart des positions, ainsi que nous l'avons deja dit, avient ete reportees e fin Novembre a fin Decembre avant la fin du mois. C'est ce qui explique l'excellente tenna de notre corbeille des valears aujourd'hui, jour des reglements. Les transactions ont porte apecialement sur l'Agricole, la National Bank, la Delta Light, la Cassa di Sconto, la Delta Land, le Trust, les Estates, l'Urbaine, le Comptoir et le Credit Franco-Egyptian, Nombre de valeurs sont en hausse notable.

La behera gagne 1/4 a 44 1/4, la Cassa di Sconto 9 franos a 257 l'ancienne et 252 la nouvelle, le Comptoir 3/16 a 7 5/8, la Building Lands 1/8 a 5 7/8, le Credit Franco-Egyptien 3/32 a 6 11/32 et la National Bank 7/32 a 28 21/32.

En hausse eralement l'Agricole de 9 13/16 a 9 27/32, la Ram'eh de 6 15/16 a 7, la Delta Light de 12 9/16 a 12 5/8, la Daira de 17 11/16 a 17 3/4, les Lots taros de 152 a 154, la Delta Land de 4 1/2 a 4 17/32, les Snereries de 29 a 29 1/2, la Khedivial Mail de 4 3/4 a 4 13/16, les Estates de 2 9/16 a 2 5/8, l'Urbaine de 7 5/8 a 7 21/32 et l'Union Fociere de 6 17/32 a 6 9/16.
Par contre, la Salt and Soda reactionne de 26/4 1/2 a 26, la Banque d'Athenes de 138 1/2 a 135 1/2, et la Banque d'Orient de 132 1/2 a 132.
Le reste de la cote eat soutenu aux cours anterieurs.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutig
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, 1er Decembre.

Le taux de l'escompte libre a Londres vient encore d'etre reduit de 1/8 a 5 5/8 pourcent. Decidement la situation monetaire tend a se detendre malgre les apprehensions causees par les demandes d'or de la part du Bresil et de l'Argentina. Au reste, le ilan, hebdomadaire publie avant-hier par la Banque d' Angleterre est rassurant: il accuseune augmentation de 1,125,000 dans l'encaisse me tallique et de 206,000 dans a reserve de billeta. L. proportion de la reserve aux engagements s'est elevee a 44 7/8 pour cent. Aussi bien, hier, au Stock Exchange, le Consolide anglais a hausse de non moins de 5/8 a 87 1/2. L'Unifies est restee invariee a 102. La National Bank a gagne a 28 1/4. L'Agricole est restee inchangee 7/8, de mame que la Daira a 17 3/4 et la Delta Light a 12 3/4.
A Paris , le Credit Froncier Egyptien a retorade de 2 francs a 788. La Banque d'Athenes est remontee de 2 francs a 138.

Ici, la seance de ce matiu a ete, dans l'ensemble, assez active sans presenter beausoup d'animation. Il y a lien toutefois de noter unbon mouvement sur la National Bank, les Egyptien et les Nungovich Hotels, ainsique sur les Estates.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a avance a 28 1/4. L'Agricole s'est maintenue a 9 13/16-7/8. Le comptoir Fiancier a est incrit a 7 7/16-1/2. La Cssa di Sconto a molli a 248. La Banque d'Athenes a gagne 3 francs a 140 sur de meilleures nouvelles de l'etat de sante de M. Pesmazoglou. La Banque d'Abyssinie est remontee a 6.

Le Credit Foncier a faibli a 787. La Daira s' est raffermie a 17 3/4 et l'Union Fonciere a 6 1/2-9/16. La Wardan Estate est revenue a 8 1/2 e sa part a 9 1/2. Enterprise and Development s'est tassee a 13 13/16 7/8 et sa part a 22 3/4 23. Les Improvements ont avarice a 7 1/8

Les Entreprises Immobilieres et Travaux sa sont consolideas a 4 3/4 et leur part a 92. La Delta Light a reactionne a 12 1/16. Les Automobiles ont ete mieux tenues a 5 3/4 et l'Anglo American Nile a 6 1/16, Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire sont remontees a 274. Les Heliopolis ont e e negociees a 336 e les Suburban a 5 5/32.
Dans le groupe devaleurs hotelieres, les Nungovich ont atteint 22 1/4 pour reactionner en eloture a 21 15/16. Les Egyptien ont gagnee environ 1/2 livre a 9 9/16. Les National se song alurdis a 4 1/8.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land, fortement attaquee par le groupe meme qui l'avait poussee, a e e ramenee 4 7/16 1/2, pour eloturer a 4 1/2, sur tontes sortes de ra meurs defavorables. O., on affirme de source autorisee que tous ces braits reposent suraueun fondement; la situation des affaires de la Societe n'aurait pas eprouve la moindre mification; il s'agirait done d'un simple monvement de specalation, Les Estates ont avance a 2 1/2-9/16 et leur part de fondatear a 19 15/16-20. Les Abdy sout rementes a 1 5/8 et les New Egyptian a . creries ont baisee a 25-26 francs
On rapporte que l'on va lauceoabment sur notre marche une nouvelie societe la "caffari's Co-operative Markets Limited."
m. Oziol, de la maison Oziol Jabes and Co., sera, dit-on, administrateur de la societe, et M> Joseph J. Jabes, de la meme maison, sera censeur.

Il y a 39,725 actions de 1 et 5,500 parts de fondateur. Ces deruieres seraient, dit-on, entierement distribuees an publc, a raison d'une part de fondateur pour huit actions souscrites. Les Promoteurs se reservent les 535 parta restantes
on ajoute que l'admission a la cote officielle des Bourses du Caire et d'Alexandrie sera de mandee.
La seme assemblee genera'e ordinaire de la Khedivial Mail Steamship and Grave Dock.
Co, aera tenue a Londres le 14 Decembre prochain.
A l'ordre du joar: rapport du conseil d'administration, presentation des comptes, fixation da dividende, nominations statutaires, etc.
On rapporte que le conseil proposers, comme pour l'exercice precedent, un dividende de 10% aur les actions ordinaires, soit 2 sh. par action, en reportant a conveau une assez forte somme.
L'assemblee generale ordinaire de la Societe des Sucreries et Raffinerie d'Egypte s'est tenue hier an sege social au Ciare.

Apresavoir confirme les ponvoirs du conseil d'administration provisoire, l'assembles a approuve le blonde 1904-1905 et donue quitus au anciens administrateurs, a l'exception de la succession de M. de la Bouglise; ces administrateurs ont vere ensemble la somme de 2,400.000 francs contre des action nonve'les
L'assemblee extraordinare convoques pour le mems jour afri de statuer sur des modification aux Statats, a ete, faute de quorum sufficiant, reavoyes au 24 Decembre.

div.head: The Alexandria Water Company Ltd.
div.p: SERVICE D'EAU FILTREE A RAMLEH.

La Compagnie prie M.M. les habitants de Ramleh, qui desirent prendre un abannement pour la fourniture de l'ean filtree, de presenter au plus tot leurs demandes par ecrit aveo l'indication exacte de la situation de leurs immenbles afin de faciliter l'etude de la canalisation necessaire.
La Compaguie establira la canlisation dans les rues, ses frais, sur une longuer a calonleo a raison de 30 metres courantes par abonaement.

Et si la distance a parcourir pour atteindre les conduites pricipales etait plus grande, la canalisation pourra etre posee quand meme, pourvu que les abonnes participent dans la depense, pour cet excelent dans les proportions a convenir.

La fourniture d l'eau filtree re sera faite que par compeur aux memes conditions et prix que ceux en viguens pour la Ville, dont M.M. les abonnes pourront preudre conuaissance en s'adressant sux bureaux de la Compagnie.
L'Administrateur-Directeur.
J. E. CORNISH.

div.head: Daira Khassa du Khedive.

Le Mardi 11 Decembre 1906 lDelta Khassa mettra en vente aux encheres Publiques au siege des Ecuries Khediviales de Boulac les animaux suivants:
1. Chevaux de race arabe et europeanne.
2. Juments diverses dont certaines sont pleines et ont e e saillies par des etalone de course.
3. Pouliches de provenance arbe.
4. Mulets, boeafs, vaches et bufles des meilleures origines.

ccording to an article published in the "Temps," M. Pichon has sent a circular to the Powers justifying the Franco-Spanish intervention in Morocco and notifying them of the action taken. No objections have been raised anywhere
Reuter
The naval division going to Morocco will stop at Cadix. Admiral Touchard will probably go to Madrid to pay a visit to the King. (H.)
Parliament has taken cognisance of the ratification of the Algeciras Convention. (H.)
The French squadron will call at Cadiz en route for tangier. Admiral Touchard will pay a visit to the King. (Feuter)

div.head:
NEW SPANISH PREMIERE.
DEMONSTRATION AGAINST CABINET.

div.p: Senor Moret has formed a new Cabinet. He will puruse the policy of his predecessors with regard to Morocco, but is less anti Clerical. (R.)
Demonstrations hostile to the new Cabinet have taken place outside the Chamber of Deputies. (Havas)

The court-martial on the mutinous sailors at Kronstadt has taken place. 683 of them have been sentenced to various terms of imprisonment and to be transferred to disciplinary battalions. 1,717 have been acquitted. (Peuter)
Colonel Boger, military attache at Tokio, and the chief of police at Kazan, while leaving the theatre yesterday evening, were shot dead. The assasin has been arrested. (Reuter)
The Tsar has appointed a committee of enquiry into the case of the Volga wheat scandal. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE KOPENICK AFFAIR
BOGUS CAPTAIN SENTENCED.

div.p: The bogus captain of Kopenick has been sentenced to 4 years' imprisonment. The Court was crowded. Hilarity greeted the duped grenadiers, the burgomaster, and other Kopenick witnesses. (Peuter)
According to a telegram received from Tokio, Japan yesterday handed over to China the administration of Niuchwang. (Peuter)

It is understood that Mr. Roosevelt is determined to press Congress to give the Federal Government power to force individual states to obey treaties. Meanwhile the Japanese question is assuming growing importance. The whole of the white population of California is resolved to exclude Japanese children from their schools. (Reuter)
WASHINGTON, December
It is announced that the Asiatic and ic squadrons will shortly be merged into the Pacific fleet under a flag officer of the highest rank. (Reuter)
The Chamber has passed the electoral reform. (Havas)
the Reicharath has adopted the Universal Sufferage Bill. This is expected to diminish the racial difficulties. (Reuter)
The King, on unveiling the statue to Andrassy, stated that he would serve as a model for future generations. (Havas)

div.head:
TELEGRAMS
EDUCATION BILL.
THE CABINET'S ATTITUDE.

div.p: Mr. Haldane, speaking at Bedford, said that unless a settlement was effected with regard to the Education question, the establishment of a secular system must result. The Lords had challenged the Government's right to its claim to have a mandate from the electors. The Cabinet was absolutely united in the necessity for taking up the challenge. (Reuter)

Mr. Lloyd George, speaking at Oxford, reudiated as absurd and ridiculous the claim of the Lords to revise the business of the Commons. If the Lords persisted in it the time would shortly come to consider whether the country should be governed by the King and the Peers, or the King and the people. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE PORTSMOUTH RIOTS.
TRIAL OF OFFICER

div.p: the admiralty has ordered Liutenant Collard, the senior officer mentioned in connection with the Portsmouth riots, to be tried by court martial. The charge is not stated, but it is understood to be in connection with the order to kneel. (Reuter)
The Sultan attended the Selamlik yesterday and afterwards received in audience the Russian and Austrian Ambassadors. (Reuter)
The Turkish troops on the Persian frontier are in a pitiable condition owing tlack of food and clothing. 500 men recently mutinied and deserted. (Reuter)
Professor Thomson, of Cambridge University, has been awarded the Nobel prize for physics. (Reuter)
Football. Rugby. The South Africans defeated Wales by 11 points to nil. (Reuter)

Unprecedented interest was exhibited at the Welsh International football match. Huge crowds were present. Eighty long-distance special trains arrived at Swansea. Wales was confident of winning: the failu is attributed to the selection of too many old players. (R.)
Oxford and Cambridge boat crews have refused the American invitation to attend the regatta in connection with the Jamestown exhibition. The King has approved their action. (Reuter)

div.head: LES SUCRERIES
div.p: L'Assemblee generale de la Societe generale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte a eu lieu hier, dans l'apres midi, sous la presidence de M. Raphael Square, president du conseil d'administration, et avec l'intervention de S.E. Harari pacha, administrateur delegue, M.H. Naus, directeur general, et Me. Cairon de Wiart, avocat conseil: Etaient representees 149,290 actions, sur 348,857.

L'Assemblee a approuv les comptes de l'exercice 1904-1905 et a ratifre l'election des nouveaux administrateurs ainsi que celle des nouveaux censeurs. Elle a accepte la demission de M.M. Barois, Arbib et Davey, et, apres avoir pris note que les anciens administrateurs des Sucreries avaient verse les 2,400,000 fracs necessaires au payment du coupon interimaire sur les actions ordinaires, elle leur a donne quitus; l'exception a ete faite pour la succession de M. de la Bouglise.
L'Assemblee generale extraordinaire a ete renvoyee au 24 decembre.
Voici les passages les plus interessants du Rapport lu a l'assemblee: Messieurs,
Les membres de l'ancien conseil qui n'etaint restes en functions que pour representer la Societe en vue du Concordat ont depuis, donne successivement leur demission.

A measure de ces demissions, le Conseil a u pourvoir au remplacement des administrateurs qui se retiraient; en vertu de l'article 18 des Status, il a disigne provisoirement, sous reserve de votre approbation, M.M. Raphel Suares, Birch pacha, Harari pacha, Leurson, de Matharel, Millet, Perier et Mahoudeau.
Et il a investi de la delegation S.E. Harari pacha.
Nous nous presentens doncedevant vous pour la premiere fois, et vous surez a voter sur le maintien ou le remplacement des membres actuels d Conseil, qui n'ont ete nommes qui'a titre provisoire.

A l'assemblee generale extraordinaire du 23 novembre 1905, l'ancien conseil vous disait que vous seriez convoques lterieurement pour examiner le Bilan definitif au 31 octobre 1905, fin de l'Exercice social, elire un nouveau Conseil et prendre part a la reconsituation de votre Societe pour le cas, bien entendu, ou elle obtiendrait de ses creanciers un Concordat defintif.
Aujourd'hui la Societe est remise a la tete de ses affaires et le conseil provisoire actuel vous convoque eu execution du programme que vous vous etes trace dans les deux assemblees precedentes.

En consequence, pour ceux d'entre vous qui n'en aurajent pas deja connaissance, nous vous remettons le Bilan au 31 octobre 1905 vise dans le rapport que les Syndios ont fait au juge commissaire a la reunion des creaners du 23 mai 1906.

Le mandat des censeurs que vous aviz designes dans votre assemblee du 5 mai 1905 etant devenu caduc et l'un d'eux, ayant au surplus quitte l'Egypte, votre conseil s'est dresse au juge des referes da tribunal mixte du Caire pour la designation d'un ou de deux nouveaux censeurs qui veriferaient le bilan c-dessus.
Le juge a designe M.M. Russel and Kerr. Nous vous convequerons ulterieurement pour la lecture et l'approbation des comptes relatifs a l'Exercice 1905-1906.

Des que le Concordat fut devenu definitif, votre Conseil s'est applique a executer les decisions que vous avez prises dans votre essemblee du 24 mars 1906 et il procede en ce moment aux operations suivantes:

1. Creation de 108,334 actions ordinaires de 100 francs au porteur, entierement liberees, devant remplacer les 325,000 actions ordinaires de 100 frs. au porteur, entierement liberees, lesquelles foimaient le capital social de francs 32,500,000. Le capital social est done reduit des 2 tiers et par suite, ramene a la somme de 0,833,400 francs.

2. Creation de 240,523 actions privilegiees de 100 frs. au porteur, entierement liberees, et remboursables a 125 frs. Le capital social de 10,833.400 est done augmente de 24,052,300 frs, ce qui le porte definitivement a 34,885,700 frs.
3. Creation de 109,000 obligations ordinaires de 400 frs au porteur, a revenu variable max. 5% et remboursables a 500frs. par tirage au sort, au plus tard en 60 ans a partir du 31 decembre 1909.

40 Creation de 40,000 obligations hypothecaires 5% de Lst. 20, u porteur amortissables au pair, a partir de 1910, et au plus tard le 1er Juin 1960, pavoie de tirage au sort annuel si les titres sont au dessus du pair, et par voie de rachat en bourse s'ils sont au dessous du pair avec afaculte pour la Societe d'augmenter ou d'anticiper les amortissements.

L'acte authentique constituant l'hypotheque consentie au profit des 22,225 obligations remises a la Daira Sanieh Sugar Corporation et des 17,775 obligations estinees a fournir les fonds de roulement de la Societe, a ete signe au greife du tribunal mixe le 30 octobre 1906.
C'est la National Bank of Egypt qui a comparu a l'acte pour accpeter l'hypotheque au profit des obligations et qui a conseuti a remplir au profit des ces titres la mission de "Trustee."
En execution du contrat que vous avez passe, lors du Concordat avec la Daira Sanieh Sugar Corporation, votre Conseil a aussi effectue la vente su Gouvernement Egyptien, des voices ferrees ex-Daira.

Cette vente a ete faite au px de Lstg. 400,000, que vous aviez autorise, et le produit a ete remis a la Daira Sanieh Sugar Corporation, en remboursement partiel de sa creance, comme il avait ete convenu au contra annexe au Concordat.

Parce paiment, par la remise la Daira Sanieh Sugar Corporation des 22,225 obligations hypothecaires et par le reglement des inteis, votre Societe se trouve entierement liberee de sa dette envers la Daira Sanieh Sugar Corporation et elle est devenue proprietaire dennitive des immeubles dont, d'apres les contrate de novembre 1902, le transfert ne devait etre opere a son profit qu'au bout de 25 annes.
Pendant la campagne 1904-1905, les Sucresies ne fibriquerent que 57.336 sacs contre 645.673 l'annee precedent.

Cet abaissement notable de la production peut etre attribue principalement aux froids exceptionnels de l'hiver 1904-1905, qui diminurent le rendement de la canne en poids et en degre; et a la preference que les cultivateurs donnerent au coton par suite des courseleves patriques alors.

La campagne 1905-1906 fut meilleure, et les usinness produisirent 624.585 sacs de sucre de ler jet dont 189,089 destines a etre livres a la consommation directe, 435.488 destines a la raffinerie, plus environ 22.000 sacs de 2 jet.

Au printempadernier, a l'epoque ou les cultuvateurs devaient determiner l'assolement de leurs terres, notre Societe se trouvait au moment le plus critique de la crise qu'elle a traversee; cette circonstance nous oblige a une grade reserve dans l'estimation des quantites probles des cannes a travailler durant la prochaine campagne; neanmoins , nous avons lieu de croire que le deficit ne sera pas trop considerable.
La Raffinerie a produit 541.595 sacs de sucre raffine en 1904-1905 et e tonnes 38.828 en 1905-1906.
sur ces quantites la consommation inte rieure a ete en 1904-1905 de tonnes 36.175 et en 1905-1906 de tonnes 36.473
Vous constaterez que la vente pour la consommation interieure s'est maintenne aux chiffres precedents.

La diminution sur la production provient uniquement de ce que votre societe a estime devoir s'abstenir pour le moment de faire des importations de sucres bruts de l'etranger, ainsi que des exportaions de ancres raffi es pour les Indes.

Par suite des dispositions prises depuis le mois d'aout 1905, les frais generaux d'exploitation ont ete sensiblement reduits; et bien que nous ne puissions vous donner aujourd'hui les comptes definitifs de l'exercice 1905-1906, nous sommes en mesure de vous dire qu'une amelioration sensible a deja ete obtenne dans les frais d'exploitation.
Nous esperons progresser encore dans cettevoie.
Ces resultats actuels n'ont ete acquis qu'au prix de grands efforts.

Les fonds disponsibles de la Societe ne s'elevaient fin aout 1905 qu'a L.E. 42,000 environ; cette somme ne representait pas le dixieme du roulement necessaire pout la campagne 1905-1906. La fermeture des usines et par suite la taillite de la Societe, la perte de toute la recolte de cannes 1905-1906 eussent ete fatales, si la Societe de la Daira Sanieh n'avait consent a faire l'avance de la majeure partie des fonds necessaires.
Nous croyons rentrer dans vos intentions en adressant a cette Societe des remerciements pour le service qu'elle a renda a la Societe et a tous les cultivateurs de cannes de la Haute-Egypte.
Poursuivant le programme que nous nous sommes trace, nous vous proposons de dimineur le plus possible les charges sociales.
Votre Societe possede en sus de ses Usines en activite des immeubles improductifs dont la valeur venale est tres appreciable.
Nous choisirons le moment opportun pour aliener tout ou partie de'ces immeubles: le prix en sera employe a l'amortissement de votre dette et diminnera ainsi les charges sociales.

Vous avez deja modifie en partie les Statuts de votre Societe son capital, vous allez nommer, en remplacement de l'ancien Conseil de nouveaux administrateurs, ou ratifier la nomination des administrateurs provisoires actuels.
Vous aurez egalement a statuer sur la de mission donne par les membres de l'ancien conseil et sur la decharge de leur mandat.

Nous n'avons pas besoin de vous rappeler que la reconstitution de la Societe a ete rendue possible par les sacrifices consentis par M.M. Dorizon, Barois, Ternynck, Arbib, Davey et Leroux, et il vous parltra sars doute equitable de donner a ces administrateurs decharge de leur mandat. Les 2,400.000 francs qui'ils se sont engages a souscrire en actions privilegiees ont ete verses par eux a votre Societe.
Vous aurez aussi, Messieure, a designer les Censeurs pour l'Exercice 1906-1907 et a fixer le montant de leur allocation.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:—
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.& O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.& O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea. No hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza.

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of Lake Maggiore, has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse.

THUN (on the Lake of Thun) half an hour from Berne and one hour from Interlaken. Quiet and quaint; sheltered from winds; just the place to rest and recuperate. Beautiful walks, through woods, and along the lake shore. Kursaal, Concernts, Casino, Races, Tennis, Boating, etc.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND. – INTERLAKEN, a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees, the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

ZURICH on the Gothard route. Direct communication with Northern Europe. Largest town in Switzerland, beautifully-situated on the lake of Zurich. Theatres. Big Concern Halls. Boating on the lake. Excellent schools. The National Museum.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: SALSOMAGGIORE (Italy.)
div.p: A pleasantly situated village lying in the valley between Piacenza and Parma, rapidly becoming famous for its waters, which are very rich in bromine and iodine and the richest in the world in lithium, strontium, and ichthyol, and have been successfully used in the treatment of scrofula, rheumatism, tuberculous affections, ladies complaints, etc.
